scenes.title: Priam Meets Achilles
scenes.summary: Priam pleads with Achilles for Hector's body.
scenes.text:
With solemn pace through various rooms he went,
And found Achilles in his inner tent:
There sat the hero: Alcimus the brave,
And great Automedon, attendance gave:
These served his person at the royal feast;
Around, at awful distance, stood the rest.
Unseen by these, the king his entry made:
And, prostrate now before Achilles laid,
Sudden (a venerable sight!) appears;
Embraced his knees, and bathed his hands in tears;
Those direful hands his kisses press'd, embrued
Even with the best, the dearest of his blood!
As when a wretch (who, conscious of his crime,
Pursued for murder, flies his native clime)
Just gains some frontier, breathless, pale, amazed,
All gaze, all wonder: thus Achilles gazed:
Thus stood the attendants stupid with surprise:
All mute, yet seem'd to question with their eyes:
Each look'd on other, none the silence broke,
Till thus at last the kingly suppliant spoke:
"Ah think, thou favour'd of the powers divine![295]
Think of thy father's age, and pity mine!
In me that father's reverend image trace,
Those silver hairs, that venerable face;
His trembling limbs, his helpless person, see!
In all my equal, but in misery!
Yet now, perhaps, some turn of human fate
Expels him helpless from his peaceful state;
Think, from some powerful foe thou seest him fly,
And beg protection with a feeble cry.
Yet still one comfort in his soul may rise;
He hears his son still lives to glad his eyes,
And, hearing, still may hope a better day
May send him thee, to chase that foe away.
No comfort to my griefs, no hopes remain,
The best, the bravest, of my sons are slain!
Yet what a race! ere Greece to Ilion came,
The pledge of many a loved and loving dame:
Nineteen one mother bore—Dead, all are dead!
How oft, alas! has wretched Priam bled!
Still one was left their loss to recompense;
His father's hope, his country's last defence.
Him too thy rage has slain! beneath thy steel,
Unhappy in his country's cause he fell!
"For him through hostile camps I bent my way,
For him thus prostrate at thy feet I lay;
Large gifts proportion'd to thy wrath I bear;
O hear the wretched, and the gods revere!
"Think of thy father, and this face behold!
See him in me, as helpless and as old!
Though not so wretched: there he yields to me,
The first of men in sovereign misery!
Thus forced to kneel, thus grovelling to embrace
The scourge and ruin of my realm and race;
Suppliant my children's murderer to implore,
And kiss those hands yet reeking with their gore!"
These words soft pity in the chief inspire,
Touch'd with the dear remembrance of his sire.
Then with his hand (as prostrate still he lay)
The old man's cheek he gently turn'd away.
Now each by turns indulged the gush of woe;
And now the mingled tides together flow:
This low on earth, that gently bending o'er;
A father one, and one a son deplore:
But great Achilles different passions rend,
And now his sire he mourns, and now his friend.
The infectious softness through the heroes ran;
One universal solemn shower began;
They bore as heroes, but they felt as man.
Satiate at length with unavailing woes,

scenes.title: Achilles Grants Request
scenes.summary: Achilles agrees to return Hector's body to Priam.
scenes.text:
From the high throne divine Achilles rose;
The reverend monarch by the hand he raised;
On his white beard and form majestic gazed,
Not unrelenting; then serene began
With words to soothe the miserable man:
"Alas, what weight of anguish hast thou known,
Unhappy prince! thus guardless and alone
To pass through foes, and thus undaunted face
The man whose fury has destroy'd thy race!
Heaven sure has arm'd thee with a heart of steel,
A strength proportion'd to the woes you feel.
Rise, then: let reason mitigate your care:
To mourn avails not: man is born to bear.
Such is, alas! the gods' severe decree:
They, only they are blest, and only free.
Two urns by Jove's high throne have ever stood,
The source of evil one, and one of good;
From thence the cup of mortal man he fills,
Blessings to these, to those distributes ill;
To most he mingles both: the wretch decreed
To taste the bad unmix'd, is cursed indeed;
Pursued by wrongs, by meagre famine driven,
He wanders, outcast both of earth and heaven.
The happiest taste not happiness sincere;
But find the cordial draught is dash'd with care.
Who more than Peleus shone in wealth and power
What stars concurring bless'd his natal hour!
A realm, a goddess, to his wishes given;
Graced by the gods with all the gifts of heaven.
One evil yet o'ertakes his latest day:
No race succeeding to imperial sway;
An only son; and he, alas! ordain'd
To fall untimely in a foreign land.
See him, in Troy, the pious care decline
Of his weak age, to live the curse of thine!
Thou too, old man, hast happier days beheld;
In riches once, in children once excell'd;
Extended Phrygia own'd thy ample reign,
And all fair Lesbos' blissful seats contain,
And all wide Hellespont's unmeasured main.
But since the god his hand has pleased to turn,
And fill thy measure from his bitter urn,
What sees the sun, but hapless heroes' falls?
War, and the blood of men, surround thy walls!
What must be, must be. Bear thy lot, nor shed
These unavailing sorrows o'er the dead;
Thou canst not call him from the Stygian shore,
But thou, alas! may'st live to suffer more!"
To whom the king: "O favour'd of the skies!
Here let me grow to earth! since Hector lies
On the bare beach deprived of obsequies.
O give me Hector! to my eyes restore
His corse, and take the gifts: I ask no more.
Thou, as thou may'st, these boundless stores enjoy;
Safe may'st thou sail, and turn thy wrath from Troy;
So shall thy pity and forbearance give
A weak old man to see the light and live!"
"Move me no more, (Achilles thus replies,
While kindling anger sparkled in his eyes,)
Nor seek by tears my steady soul to bend:
To yield thy Hector I myself intend:
For know, from Jove my goddess-mother came,
(Old Ocean's daughter, silver-footed dame,)
Nor comest thou but by heaven; nor comest alone,
Some god impels with courage not thy own:
No human hand the weighty gates unbarr'd,
Nor could the boldest of our youth have dared
To pass our outworks, or elude the guard.
Cease; lest, neglectful of high Jove's command,
I show thee, king! thou tread'st on hostile land;
Release my knees, thy suppliant arts give o'er,
And shake the purpose of my soul no more."
The sire obey'd him, trembling and o'eraw'd.
Achilles, like a lion, rush'd abroad:
Automedon and Alcimus attend,
(Whom most he honour'd, since he lost his friend,)
These to unyoke the mules and horses went,
And led the hoary herald to the tent;
Next, heap'd on high, the numerous presents bear,
(Great Hector's ransom,) from the polish'd car.
Two splendid mantles, and a carpet spread,
They leave: to cover and enwrap the dead.
Then call the handmaids, with assistant toil
To wash the body and anoint with oil,
Apart from Priam: lest the unhappy sire,
Provoked to passion, once more rouse to ire
The stern Pelides; and nor sacred age,
Nor Jove's command, should check the rising rage.
This done, the garments o'er the corse they spread;
Achilles lifts it to the funeral bed:
Then, while the body on the car they laid,
He groans, and calls on loved Patroclus' shade:
"If, in that gloom which never light must know,
The deeds of mortals touch the ghosts below,
O friend! forgive me, that I thus fulfil
(Restoring Hector) heaven's unquestion'd will.
The gifts the father gave, be ever thine,
To grace thy manes, and adorn thy shrine."[296]
He said, and, entering, took his seat of state;
Where full before him reverend Priam sate;
To whom, composed, the godlike chief begun:
"Lo! to thy prayer restored, thy breathless son;
Extended on the funeral couch he lies;
And soon as morning paints the eastern skies,
The sight is granted to thy longing eyes:
But now the peaceful hours of sacred night
Demand reflection, and to rest invite:
Nor thou, O father! thus consumed with woe,
The common cares that nourish life forego.
Not thus did Niobe, of form divine,
A parent once, whose sorrows equall'd thine:
Six youthful sons, as many blooming maids,
In one sad day beheld the Stygian shades;
Those by Apollo's silver bow were slain,
These, Cynthia's arrows stretch'd upon the plain:
So was her pride chastised by wrath divine,
Who match'd her own with bright Latona's line;
But two the goddess, twelve the queen enjoy'd;
Those boasted twelve, the avenging two destroy'd.
Steep'd in their blood, and in the dust outspread,
Nine days, neglected, lay exposed the dead;
None by to weep them, to inhume them none;
(For Jove had turn'd the nation all to stone.)
The gods themselves, at length relenting gave
The unhappy race the honours of a grave.
Herself a rock (for such was heaven's high will)
Through deserts wild now pours a weeping rill;
Where round the bed whence Achelous springs,
The watery fairies dance in mazy rings;
There high on Sipylus's shaggy brow,
She stands, her own sad monument of woe;
The rock for ever lasts, the tears for ever flow.
"Such griefs, O king! have other parents known;
Remember theirs, and mitigate thy own.
The care of heaven thy Hector has appear'd,
Nor shall he lie unwept, and uninterr'd;
Soon may thy aged cheeks in tears be drown'd,
And all the eyes of Ilion stream around."
He said, and, rising, chose the victim ewe
With silver fleece, which his attendants slew.
The limbs they sever from the reeking hide,
With skill prepare them, and in parts divide:
Each on the coals the separate morsels lays,
And, hasty, snatches from the rising blaze.
With bread the glittering canisters they load,
Which round the board Automedon bestow'd.
The chief himself to each his portion placed,
And each indulging shared in sweet repast.
When now the rage of hunger was repress'd,
The wondering hero eyes his royal guest:
No less the royal guest the hero eyes,
His godlike aspect and majestic size;
Here, youthful grace and noble fire engage;
And there, the mild benevolence of age.
Thus gazing long, the silence neither broke,
(A solemn scene!) at length the father spoke:
"Permit me now, beloved of Jove! to steep
My careful temples in the dew of sleep:
For, since the day that number'd with the dead
My hapless son, the dust has been my bed;
Soft sleep a stranger to my weeping eyes;
My only food, my sorrows and my sighs!
Till now, encouraged by the grace you give,
I share thy banquet, and consent to live."
With that, Achilles bade prepare the bed,
With purple soft and shaggy carpets spread;
Forth, by the flaming lights, they bend their way,
And place the couches, and the coverings lay.
Then he: "Now, father, sleep, but sleep not here;
Consult thy safety, and forgive my fear,
Lest any Argive, at this hour awake,
To ask our counsel, or our orders take,
Approaching sudden to our open'd tent,
Perchance behold thee, and our grace prevent.
Should such report thy honour'd person here,
The king of men the ransom might defer;
But say with speed, if aught of thy desire
Remains unask'd; what time the rites require
To inter thy Hector? For, so long we stay
Our slaughtering arm, and bid the hosts obey."

characters.quote: Such is, alas! the gods' severe decree: They, only they are blest, and only free.

characters.importance_exp: The respect shown in the burial rites highlights the theme of honor.
characters.quote: Nor shall he lie unwept, and uninterr'd; Soon may thy aged cheeks in tears be drown'd.

characters.importance_exp: Achilles' willingness to return Hector's body shows compassion despite his anger.

scenes.title: Hector's Funeral
scenes.summary: The Trojans mourn and prepare for Hector's funeral.
scenes.text:
"If then thy will permit (the monarch said)
To finish all due honours to the dead,
This of thy grace accord: to thee are known
The fears of Ilion, closed within her town;
And at what distance from our walls aspire
The hills of Ide, and forests for the fire.
Nine days to vent our sorrows I request,
The tenth shall see the funeral and the feast;
The next, to raise his monument be given;
The twelfth we war, if war be doom'd by heaven!"
"This thy request (replied the chief) enjoy:
Till then our arms suspend the fall of Troy."
Then gave his hand at parting, to prevent
The old man's fears, and turn'd within the tent;
Where fair Briseïs, bright in blooming charms,
Expects her hero with desiring arms.
But in the porch the king and herald rest;
Sad dreams of care yet wandering in their breast.
Now gods and men the gifts of sleep partake;
Industrious Hermes only was awake,
The king's return revolving in his mind,
To pass the ramparts, and the watch to blind.
The power descending hover'd o'er his head:
"And sleep'st thou, father! (thus the vision said:)
Now dost thou sleep, when Hector is restored?
Nor fear the Grecian foes, or Grecian lord?
Thy presence here should stern Atrides see,
Thy still surviving sons may sue for thee;
May offer all thy treasures yet contain,
To spare thy age; and offer all in vain."
Waked with the word the trembling sire arose,
And raised his friend: the god before him goes:
He joins the mules, directs them with his hand,
And moves in silence through the hostile land.
When now to Xanthus' yellow stream they drove,
(Xanthus, immortal progeny of Jove,)
The winged deity forsook their view,
And in a moment to Olympus flew.
Now shed Aurora round her saffron ray,
Sprang through the gates of light, and gave the day:
Charged with the mournful load, to Ilion go
The sage and king, majestically slow.
Cassandra first beholds, from Ilion's spire,
The sad procession of her hoary sire;
Then, as the pensive pomp advanced more near,
(Her breathless brother stretched upon the bier,)
A shower of tears o'erflows her beauteous eyes,
Alarming thus all Ilion with her cries:
"Turn here your steps, and here your eyes employ,
Ye wretched daughters, and ye sons of Troy!
If e'er ye rush'd in crowds, with vast delight,
To hail your hero glorious from the fight,
Now meet him dead, and let your sorrows flow;
Your common triumph, and your common woe."
In thronging crowds they issue to the plains;
Nor man nor woman in the walls remains;
In every face the self-same grief is shown;
And Troy sends forth one universal groan.
At Scæa's gates they meet the mourning wain,
Hang on the wheels, and grovel round the slain.
The wife and mother, frantic with despair,
Kiss his pale cheek, and rend their scatter'd hair:
Thus wildly wailing, at the gates they lay;
And there had sigh'd and sorrow'd out the day;
But godlike Priam from the chariot rose:
"Forbear (he cried) this violence of woes;
First to the palace let the car proceed,
Then pour your boundless sorrows o'er the dead."
The waves of people at his word divide,
Slow rolls the chariot through the following tide;
Even to the palace the sad pomp they wait:
They weep, and place him on the bed of state.
A melancholy choir attend around,
With plaintive sighs, and music's solemn sound:
Alternately they sing, alternate flow
The obedient tears, melodious in their woe.
While deeper sorrows groan from each full heart,
And nature speaks at every pause of art.
First to the corse the weeping consort flew;
Around his neck her milk-white arms she threw,
"And oh, my Hector! Oh, my lord! (she cries)
Snatch'd in thy bloom from these desiring eyes!
Thou to the dismal realms for ever gone!
And I abandon'd, desolate, alone!
An only son, once comfort of our pains,
Sad product now of hapless love, remains!
Never to manly age that son shall rise,
Or with increasing graces glad my eyes:
For Ilion now (her great defender slain)
Shall sink a smoking ruin on the plain.
Who now protects her wives with guardian care?
Who saves her infants from the rage of war?
Now hostile fleets must waft those infants o'er
(Those wives must wait them) to a foreign shore:
Thou too, my son, to barbarous climes shall go,
The sad companion of thy mother's woe;
Driven hence a slave before the victor's sword
Condemn'd to toil for some inhuman lord:
Or else some Greek whose father press'd the plain,
Or son, or brother, by great Hector slain,
In Hector's blood his vengeance shall enjoy,
And hurl thee headlong from the towers of Troy.[297]
For thy stern father never spared a foe:
Thence all these tears, and all this scene of woe!
Thence many evils his sad parents bore,
His parents many, but his consort more.
Why gav'st thou not to me thy dying hand?
And why received not I thy last command?
Some word thou would'st have spoke, which, sadly dear,
My soul might keep, or utter with a tear;
Which never, never could be lost in air,
Fix'd in my heart, and oft repeated there!"
Thus to her weeping maids she makes her moan,
Her weeping handmaids echo groan for groan.
The mournful mother next sustains her part:
"O thou, the best, the dearest to my heart!
Of all my race thou most by heaven approved,
And by the immortals even in death beloved!
While all my other sons in barbarous bands
Achilles bound, and sold to foreign lands,
This felt no chains, but went a glorious ghost,
Free, and a hero, to the Stygian coast.
Sentenced, 'tis true, by his inhuman doom,
Thy noble corse was dragg'd around the tomb;
(The tomb of him thy warlike arm had slain;)
Ungenerous insult, impotent and vain!
Yet glow'st thou fresh with every living grace;
No mark of pain, or violence of face:
Rosy and fair! as Phœbus' silver bow
Dismiss'd thee gently to the shades below."
Thus spoke the dame, and melted into tears.
Sad Helen next in pomp of grief appears;
Fast from the shining sluices of her eyes
Fall the round crystal drops, while thus she cries.
"Ah, dearest friend! in whom the gods had join'd[298]
The mildest manners with the bravest mind,
Now twice ten years (unhappy years) are o'er
Since Paris brought me to the Trojan shore,
(O had I perish'd, ere that form divine
Seduced this soft, this easy heart of mine!)
Yet was it ne'er my fate, from thee to find
A deed ungentle, or a word unkind.
When others cursed the authoress of their woe,
Thy pity check'd my sorrows in their flow.
If some proud brother eyed me with disdain,
Or scornful sister with her sweeping train,
Thy gentle accents soften'd all my pain.
For thee I mourn, and mourn myself in thee,
The wretched source of all this misery.
The fate I caused, for ever I bemoan;
Sad Helen has no friend, now thou art gone!
Through Troy's wide streets abandon'd shall I roam!
In Troy deserted, as abhorr'd at home!"
So spoke the fair, with sorrow-streaming eye.
Distressful beauty melts each stander-by.
On all around the infectious sorrow grows;
But Priam check'd the torrent as it rose:
"Perform, ye Trojans! what the rites require,
And fell the forests for a funeral pyre;
Twelve days, nor foes nor secret ambush dread;
Achilles grants these honours to the dead."[299]
[Illustration: ] FUNERAL OF HECTOR
He spoke, and, at his word, the Trojan train
Their mules and oxen harness to the wain,
Pour through the gates, and fell'd from Ida's crown,
Roll back the gather'd forests to the town.
These toils continue nine succeeding days,
And high in air a sylvan structure raise.
But when the tenth fair morn began to shine,
Forth to the pile was borne the man divine,
And placed aloft; while all, with streaming eyes,
Beheld the flames and rolling smokes arise.
Soon as Aurora, daughter of the dawn,
With rosy lustre streak'd the dewy lawn,
Again the mournful crowds surround the pyre,
And quench with wine the yet remaining fire.
The snowy bones his friends and brothers place
(With tears collected) in a golden vase;
The golden vase in purple palls they roll'd,
Of softest texture, and inwrought with gold.
Last o'er the urn the sacred earth they spread,
And raised the tomb, memorial of the dead.
(Strong guards and spies, till all the rites were done,
Watch'd from the rising to the setting sun.)
All Troy then moves to Priam's court again,
A solemn, silent, melancholy train:
Assembled there, from pious toil they rest,
And sadly shared the last sepulchral feast.
Such honours Ilion to her hero paid,
And peaceful slept the mighty Hector's shade.

characters.name: Grief And Mourning
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the scene as it depicts the collective sorrow of the Trojans over Hector's death.
characters.quote: Now meet him dead, and let your sorrows flow; Your common triumph, and your common woe.

characters.name: Honor And Respect
characters.importance_exp: The scene emphasizes the importance of honoring Hector through funeral rites.
characters.quote: Achilles grants these honours to the dead.

characters.name: Heroism And Valor
characters.importance_exp: Hector's legacy as a hero is highlighted through the mourning and honors given to him.
characters.quote: Thus spoke the dame, and melted into tears.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.quote: entreats for vengeance from his god; who inflicts a pestilence on the Greeks.
characters.explanation: This soft, ethereal color represents the divine presence and intervention of the gods in human affairs.

characters.name: Pride And Honor
characters.quote: the king, being obliged to send back his captive, enters into a furious contest with Achilles.
characters.explanation: Gold represents the themes of pride and honor, reflecting the high stakes of personal and collective honor.

characters.name: Conflict And Division
characters.quote: Achilles in discontent withdraws himself and his forces from the rest of the Greeks;
characters.explanation: Deep pink symbolizes the conflict and division among the characters.

characters.name: Wrath And Revenge
characters.quote: Achilles' wrath, to Greece the direful spring Of woes unnumber'd, heavenly goddess, sing!
characters.explanation: Orange-red symbolizes the intense emotions of wrath and the desire for revenge.

characters.name: Suffering And Loss
characters.quote: The trembling priest along the shore return'd, And in the anguish of a father mourn'd.
characters.explanation: Gray represents the themes of suffering and loss, reflecting the somber realities of war.

characters.name: Leadership And Authority
characters.quote: Know, if the god the beauteous dame demand, My bark shall waft her to her native land;
characters.explanation: Blue signifies authority and leadership, reflecting the commanding presence of leaders.

characters.name: Sacrifice And Atonement
characters.quote: With pure lustrations, and with solemn prayers.
characters.explanation: Orange symbolizes the themes of sacrifice and the quest for atonement.

characters.name: Isolation
characters.quote: Nor mix'd in combat, nor in council join'd;

characters.name: Inner Turmoil
characters.quote: But wasting cares lay heavy on his mind:

characters.name: Violence And Bloodshed
characters.quote: And scenes of blood rise dreadful in his soul.
characters.explanation: Dark red symbolizes the violence and bloodshed that occur throughout the conflict.

characters.name: Power Dynamics
characters.quote: What hast thou ask'd? ah, why should Jove engage

characters.name: Fate And Destiny
characters.quote: The stamp of fate and sanction of the god:
characters.explanation: Purple signifies the inevitability of fate and the weight of destiny that hangs over the characters.

characters.name: Respect For The Gods
characters.quote: The united strength of all the gods above In vain resists the omnipotence of Jove.

characters.name: Jealousy And Fear
characters.quote: But 'tis for Greece I fear: for late was seen, In close consult, the silver-footed queen.
characters.explanation: Green represents jealousy and fear, often associated with envy and insecurity.

characters.name: Intervention And Mediation
characters.quote: Let men their days in senseless strife employ, We, in eternal peace and constant joy.

characters.name: Deception
characters.quote: Jupiter, in pursuance of the request of Thetis, sends a deceitful vision to Agamemnon, persuading him to lead the army to battle.

characters.name: Leadership
characters.quote: He first communicates his design to the princes in council, that he would propose a return to the soldiers.
characters.explanation: Cyan represents the qualities of leadership and the responsibilities that come with it.

characters.name: Shame And Infamy
characters.quote: Shall then the Grecians fly! O dire disgrace!

characters.name: Call To Arms
characters.quote: Now bid thy heralds sound the loud alarms, And call the squadrons sheathed in brazen arms;

characters.name: Unity
characters.quote: Thus numerous and confused, extending wide, The legions crowd Scamander's flowery side;
characters.explanation: Light green symbolizes unity and togetherness in the face of adversity.

characters.name: Heroism And Valor
characters.quote: "Now bid thy heralds sound the loud alarms, And call the squadrons sheathed in brazen arms;"
characters.explanation: Red symbolizes courage and bravery, reflecting the heroic actions of the warriors.

characters.name: Mortality
characters.quote: "Death's sable shade at once o'ercast their eyes, In dust the vanquish'd and the victor lies."

characters.name: Love And Betrayal
characters.quote: "Thy love the motive, and thy charms the prize."
characters.explanation: Hot pink represents the complexities of love and betrayal.

characters.name: Honor And War
characters.quote: "He dares the Spartan king to single fight;"

characters.name: Fate And Intervention
characters.quote: "What my soul prompts, and what some god commands."

characters.name: Honor In Combat
characters.quote: "To combat born, and bred amidst alarms:"

characters.name: Desire For Peace
characters.quote: "Let Sparta's treasures be this hour restored, And Argive Helen own her ancient lord."

characters.name: War And Peace
characters.quote: "Let a truce be ask'd, that Troy may burn Her slaughter'd heroes, and their bones inurn;"

characters.name: Family And Loyalty
characters.quote: "My brothers, friends, and daughter left behind, False to them all, to Paris only kind!"
characters.explanation: Peach represents the themes of family and loyalty, reflecting warmth and connection.

characters.name: Beauty And Desire
characters.quote: "The matchless Helen, o'er the walls reclined"

characters.name: Conflict And Honor
characters.quote: "Each sounds your praise, and war is all your own."

characters.name: Victory And Honor
characters.quote: "Ye Trojans, Dardans, all our generous foes!"

characters.name: Heroic Ambition
characters.quote: "What praise were thine, couldst thou direct thy dart, Amidst his triumph, to the Spartan's heart?"

characters.name: Consequences Of War
characters.quote: "With copious slaughter all the fields are red, And heap'd with growing mountains of the dead."

characters.name: Discipline
characters.quote: "Nor cause confusion, nor the ranks exceed:"

characters.name: Courage
characters.quote: "But fight, or fall; a firm embodied train."
characters.explanation: Dark blue symbolizes courage and the strength to face challenges.

characters.name: Strategy
characters.quote: "Thus ruled their ardour, thus preserved their force;"

characters.name: Glory And Sacrifice
characters.quote: "So fought each host, with thirst of glory fired, And crowds on crowds triumphantly expired."
characters.explanation: A warm orange symbolizes the glory that comes from sacrifice.

characters.name: Healing And Restoration
characters.quote: "And heal'd the immortal flesh, and closed the wound."

characters.name: Friendship
characters.quote: they make exchange of their arms.
characters.explanation: Light blue represents the bonds of friendship and camaraderie among the characters.

characters.name: Duty And Honor
characters.quote: Hector, having performed the orders of Helenus, prevails upon Paris to return to the battle.

characters.name: Mercy And Justice
characters.quote: Not one of all the race, nor sex, nor age, Shall save a Trojan from our boundless rage: Ilion shall perish whole, and bury all; Her babes, her infants at the breast, shall fall;

characters.name: Conflict And Duty
characters.quote: What pity sloth should seize a soul so brave, Or godlike Paris live a woman's slave!

characters.name: Truce And Diplomacy
characters.quote: Antenor purposes the delivery of Helen to the Greeks.

characters.name: Fearlessness In Battle
characters.quote: Born to combats, fear no force on earth.

characters.name: Wrath And Resentment
characters.quote: Indulge his wrath, and aid our arms no more;

characters.name: Generosity
characters.quote: The generous Greek bestow'd

characters.name: Honor
characters.quote: A radiant belt that rich with purple glow'd

characters.name: Grief And Mourning
characters.quote: What Greeks are perish'd! what a people lost!
characters.explanation: Indigo signifies deep grief and mourning, reflecting the emotional weight of loss.

characters.name: Defense And Security
characters.quote: They raised embattled walls with lofty towers

characters.name: Strength And Resilience
characters.quote: Strong piles infix'd stood adverse to the foe

characters.name: Celebration And Feast
characters.quote: All night they feast, the Greek and Trojan powers:

characters.name: Courage And Honor
characters.quote: O'erwhelm me, earth; and hide a warrior's shame!

characters.name: Desperation In Battle
characters.quote: Through broken orders, swifter than the wind, He fled, but flying left his life behind.

characters.name: Conflict And Rage
characters.quote: Still swells the slaughter, and still grows the rage!

characters.name: Hope And Despair
characters.quote: Better from evils, well foreseen, to run, Than perish in the danger we may shun.

characters.name: Divine Wrath
characters.quote: No quote available

characters.name: Unity And Leadership
characters.quote: Ye valiant Trojans, with attention hear!

characters.name: Crisis And Despair
characters.quote: Whom Jove decrees with daily cares to bend, And woes, that only with his life shall end!

characters.name: Death And Destruction
characters.quote: And a low groan remurmur'd through the shore.

characters.name: Warrior Preparation
characters.quote: Himself first rose, himself before the rest His mighty limbs in radiant armour dress'd,

characters.name: Violence And Death
characters.quote: The woes of men unwilling to survey, And all the slaughters that must stain the day.

characters.name: Revenge And Retribution
characters.quote: But in his front he felt the fatal wound, Which pierced his brain, and stretch'd him on the ground.

characters.name: Futility Of War
characters.quote: Vain was their youth, their glittering armour vain: Now soil'd with dust, and naked to the sky, Their snowy limbs and beauteous bodies lie.

characters.name: Valor And Honor
characters.quote: The king's example all his Greeks pursue.

characters.name: Suffering
characters.quote: Oh worthy better fate! oh early slain!

characters.name: Motivation And Rallying
characters.quote: Now call to mind your ancient trophies won, Your great forefathers' virtues, and your own.

characters.name: Chaos Of Battle
characters.quote: Thus obstinate to death, they fight, they fall; Nor these can keep, nor those can win the wall.

characters.name: Conflict And Struggle
characters.quote: Thus while the morning-beams, increasing bright, O'er heaven's pure azure spread the glowing light, Commutual death the fate of war confounds, Each adverse battle gored with equal wounds.

characters.name: Courage Vs. Cowardice
characters.quote: Without a sign his sword the brave man draws, And asks no omen but his country's cause.

characters.name: Destruction And Ruin
characters.quote: Now smooth'd with sand, and levell'd by the flood, No fragment tells where once the wonder stood;

characters.name: Omen And Fate
characters.quote: The eternal Monarch, on his awful throne, Wrapt in the blaze of boundless glory sate; And fix'd, fulfill'd the just decrees of fate.

characters.name: Struggle And Conflict
characters.quote: Thus while the morning-beams, increasing bright, O'er heaven's pure azure spread the glowing light, Commutual death the fate of war confounds, Each adverse battle gored with equal wounds.

characters.name: Destruction And Chaos
characters.quote: The crowded bulwarks blaze with waving arms, Shield touching shield, a long refulgent row; Whence hissing darts, incessant, rain below.

characters.name: Fear And Flight
characters.quote: The Greeks behold, they tremble, and they fly; The shore is heap'd with death, and tumult rends the sky.

characters.name: Nature's Indifference
characters.quote: Thrice happy race! that, innocent of blood, From milk, innoxious, seek their simple food:

characters.name: Despair And Hope
characters.quote: O Jove! if ever, on his native shore, One Greek enrich'd thy shrine with offer'd gore;

characters.name: Divine Inspiration
characters.quote: The presence of gods motivates the heroes.

characters.name: Internal Conflict
characters.quote: While wavering counsels thus his mind engage, Fluctuates in doubtful thought the Pylian sage, To join the host, or to the general haste;

characters.name: Honor And Valor
characters.quote: "Lives there a man so dead to fame, who dares To think such meanness, or the thought declares?"

characters.name: Pride And Wrath
characters.quote: "Blind, impious man! whose anger is his guide, Who glories in unutterable pride."

characters.name: Death And Loss
characters.quote: "Lamented youth! in life's first bloom he fell, Sent by great Ajax to the shades of hell."

characters.name: Heroic Fall
characters.quote: "So lies great Hector prostrate on the shore; His slacken'd hand deserts the lance it bore;"

characters.name: Memory And Reflection
characters.quote: "In thought a length of lands he trod before"

characters.name: Rebellion
characters.quote: "No vassal god, nor of his train, am I."

characters.name: Mortality And Death
characters.quote: "Even yet, methinks, the gliding ghosts I spy, And hell's black horrors swim before my eye."

characters.name: War And Duty
characters.quote: "O friends! O heroes! names for ever dear, Once sons of Mars, and thunderbolts of war!"

characters.name: Revenge
characters.quote: "Revenge, revenge it on the cruel foe."

characters.name: Leadership And Inspiration
characters.quote: "His generous sense he not in vain imparts; It sunk, and rooted in the Grecian hearts:"

characters.name: Desperation
characters.quote: "No aids, no bulwarks your retreat attend,"

characters.name: Conflict
characters.quote: "The warring nations meet, the battle roars,"

characters.name: Brotherhood In Arms
characters.quote: "Two friends, two bodies with one soul inspired."

characters.name: Maternal Grief
characters.quote: "The horses of Achilles deplore the loss of Patroclus."
characters.explanation: Light pink represents the tenderness and sorrow of maternal grief.

characters.name: Fear And Despair
characters.quote: "His words infix'd unutterable care Deep in great Hector's soul: through all the war He darts his anxious eye;"

characters.name: Hope And Expectation
characters.quote: "Expects him glorious from the conquered plain, And for his wish'd return prepares in vain;"

characters.name: Conflict And Strategy
characters.quote: "Hector and Polydamas disagree in their opinions: but the advice of the former prevails."

characters.name: Creation And Craftsmanship
characters.quote: "The description of the wonderful works of Vulcan:"

characters.name: Fury And Desperation
characters.quote: "Urge to broad Hellespont their headlong course;"

characters.name: Loss And Mourning
characters.quote: Achilles and the Myrmidons do honours to the body of Patroclus.

characters.name: Desperation For Survival
characters.quote: For Troy, for Troy, shall henceforth be the strife, And the hard contest not for fame, but life.

characters.name: Reconciliation
characters.quote: Agamemnon and Achilles are solemnly reconciled.

characters.name: Fury And Revenge
characters.quote: Revenge is all my soul! no meaner care, Interest, or thought, has room to harbour there; Destruction be my feast, and mortal wounds, And scenes of blood, and agonizing sounds.

characters.name: Honor And Warfare
characters.quote: Now to the bloody battle let me bend: But ah! the relics of my slaughter'd friend!

characters.name: Mortality And Decay
characters.quote: Shall flies, and worms obscene, pollute the dead?

characters.name: Redemption
characters.quote: Achilles, moved with compassion, grants his request, detains him one night in his tent, and the next morning sends him home with the body.

characters.name: Flight And Escape
characters.quote: Now chased, and trembling in ignoble flight:

characters.name: Pity And Suplication
characters.quote: Thy well-known captive, great Achilles! see, Once more Lycaon trembles at thy knee.

characters.name: Divine Conflict
characters.quote: The warring gods in fierce contention join:

characters.name: Honor And Respect
characters.quote: Thee first in virtue, as in power supreme, O king of nations! all thy Greeks proclaim;

characters.name: Commemoration And Legacy
characters.quote: Achilles institutes the funeral games: the chariot-race, the fight of the caestus, the wrestling, the foot-race, the single combat, the discus, the shooting with arrows, the darting the javelin.

characters.name: Honor And Duty
characters.quote: Till on the pyre I place thee; till I rear The grassy mound, and clip thy sacred hair.

characters.name: Ritual And Honor
characters.quote: With mules and waggons sends a chosen band to load the timber, and the pile to rear;

characters.name: Skill Vs. Strength
characters.quote: It is not strength, but art, obtains the prize.

characters.name: Wisdom Of Experience
characters.quote: Fear not thy rivals, though for swiftness known; Compare those rivals' judgment and thy own:

characters.name: Competition
characters.quote: Who hope the palm of swiftness to obtain, Stand forth, and bear these prizes from the plain.

characters.name: Mortality And Fate
characters.quote: Heaven dooms each mortal, and its will is done:

characters.name: Family And Duty
characters.quote: The lamentations of Andromache, Hecuba, and Helen, with the solemnities of the funeral.

characters.name: Power And Vulnerability
characters.quote: A lion, not a man, who slaughters wide, In strength of rage, and impotence of pride;

characters.name: Pity And Compassion
characters.quote: These words soft pity in the chief inspire,

locations.name: Greek Camp
locations.quote: The Greek camp was filled with the sounds of warriors preparing for battle, their spirits high as they awaited the call to arms.

locations.name: Trojan Shore
locations.quote: The Trojan shore was a sight of beauty, yet it bore witness to the bloodshed that would soon stain its sands.

locations.name: Achilles' Camp
locations.quote: In Achilles' camp, the air was thick with tension as the greatest warrior prepared for the inevitable clash.

locations.name: Olympus
locations.quote: On Olympus, the gods watched with bated breath, their fates intertwined with those of mortals below.

locations.name: Agamemnon's Tent
locations.quote: Inside Agamemnon's tent, plans were laid and strategies devised, the weight of leadership heavy on his shoulders.

locations.name: Battlefield Of Troy
locations.quote: The battlefield of Troy was a chaotic symphony of clashing swords and cries of valor, where heroes were made and lost.

locations.name: Troy
locations.quote: Troy stood proud and defiant, its walls a testament to the strength of its people amidst the storm of war.

locations.name: Helen's Palace
locations.quote: In Helen's palace, whispers of love and betrayal echoed, a reminder of the beauty that sparked the flames of war.

locations.name: Trojan Assembly
locations.quote: The Trojan assembly gathered to discuss their fate, united in purpose yet divided by fear.

locations.name: Feast After Battle
locations.quote: The feast after battle was a bittersweet celebration, honoring the fallen while reveling in hard-won victories.

locations.name: Two Camps
locations.quote: The two camps stood opposite each other, a stark reminder of the division that war had wrought among former allies.

locations.name: Field Near Ilus
locations.quote: The field near Ilus was a quiet place, soon to be stained with the blood of heroes and the cries of the dying.

locations.name: Neptune's Palace
locations.quote: In Neptune's palace, the god of the sea pondered the fate of the warriors, his heart heavy with the weight of their struggles.

locations.name: By The Stream
locations.quote: By the stream, soldiers found brief respite, the water a soothing balm amidst the chaos of war.

locations.name: In The Tent
locations.quote: In the tent, plans were forged and alliances tested, the air thick with the scent of oil and sweat.

locations.name: Vulcan's Palace
locations.quote: Vulcan's palace was a forge of creation, where divine craftsmanship met the needs of the greatest heroes.

locations.name: Council Of The Greeks
locations.quote: The council of the Greeks was a gathering of minds, each voice adding to the chorus of strategy and resolve.

locations.name: River Scamander
locations.quote: The river Scamander flowed with the memories of battles past, its waters a silent witness to the horrors of war.

locations.name: Olympus And Troy
locations.quote: The connection between Olympus and Troy was palpable, as the gods intervened in the affairs of mortals below.

locations.name: Funeral Of Patroclus
locations.quote: The funeral of Patroclus was a somber affair, a testament to friendship and the cost of war.

locations.name: Greek Games
locations.quote: The Greek games celebrated strength and skill, a reminder of the glory that once was before the war began.

locations.name: Thetis' Cave
locations.quote: In Thetis' cave, the goddess mourned her son, her heart heavy with the weight of impending loss.

locations.name: Troy's Funeral Pyre
locations.quote: Troy's funeral pyre burned brightly, a symbol of the sacrifices made in the name of honor and love.
